ohm law: Ohm’s Law states that the current through a conductor is directly proportional to the voltage across it, provided temperature remains constant. V = I × R.
kirchhoff voltage law: Kirchhoff’s Voltage Law states that the algebraic sum of all voltages in any closed loop of a circuit is zero.
kirchhoff current law: Kirchhoff’s Current Law states that the total current entering a node is equal to the total current leaving the node.
resistor: A resistor is a passive electronic component that limits or regulates the flow of electrical current in a circuit.
capacitor: A capacitor is a device that stores electrical energy in the form of an electric field between two plates.
inductor: An inductor is an electronic component that stores energy in the form of a magnetic field when current flows through it.
semiconductor: A semiconductor is a material whose electrical conductivity lies between that of a conductor and an insulator. Example: silicon.
diode: A diode is a semiconductor device that allows current to flow in only one direction.
zener diode: A Zener diode is designed to operate in reverse bias and is commonly used for voltage regulation.
transistor: A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals.
bjt: A Bipolar Junction Transistor is a current-controlled device that has three terminals: emitter, base, and collector.
mosfet: A MOSFET is a voltage-controlled semiconductor device used for switching and amplification.
amplifier: An amplifier is an electronic circuit that increases the amplitude of a signal without changing its waveform.
operational amplifier: An operational amplifier is a high-gain voltage amplifier with differential inputs and a single output.
rectifier: A rectifier is a circuit that converts alternating current into direct current.
filter: A filter is a circuit that allows certain frequency components to pass and blocks others.
modulation: Modulation is the process of varying a carrier signal with a message signal to enable long-distance communication.
amplitude modulation: Amplitude Modulation is a technique where the amplitude of the carrier signal is varied according to the message signal.
frequency modulation: Frequency Modulation is a technique where the frequency of the carrier wave is varied according to the message signal.
phase modulation: Phase Modulation is a technique where the phase of the carrier is varied based on the message signal.
demodulation: Demodulation is the process of extracting the original message signal from the modulated carrier.
signal: A signal is a time-varying electrical quantity that carries information.
analog signal: An analog signal is a continuous-time signal with infinite possible values.
digital signal: A digital signal is a discrete-time signal with finite possible values, usually 0 and 1.
nyquist theorem: Nyquist theorem states that the sampling frequency must be at least twice the maximum frequency of the signal.
sampling: Sampling is the process of converting a continuous-time signal into a discrete-time signal.
quantization: Quantization is the process of converting continuous signal amplitudes into discrete levels.
bandwidth: Bandwidth is the range of frequencies over which a system can operate effectively.
antenna: An antenna is a device used to transmit or receive electromagnetic waves.
waveguide: A waveguide is a structure that guides electromagnetic waves from one point to another.
radar: Radar is a system that uses radio waves to detect the distance, direction, and speed of objects.
communication system: A communication system is a collection of devices that transfer information from one place to another.
noise: Noise is any unwanted signal that interferes with the original signal.
signal to noise ratio: Signal-to-noise ratio is the ratio of signal power to noise power and measures signal quality.
multiplexing: Multiplexing is the technique of transmitting multiple signals over a single communication channel.
time division multiplexing: In TDM, multiple signals share the same channel in different time slots.
frequency division multiplexing: In FDM, multiple signals share the same channel using different frequency bands.
microprocessor: A microprocessor is a programmable digital device that performs arithmetic and logical operations.
microcontroller: A microcontroller is a compact integrated circuit that includes processor, memory, and input/output peripherals.
logic gate: A logic gate is a basic digital circuit that performs a logical operation.
flip flop: A flip-flop is a bistable digital circuit used for storing one bit of information.
counter: A counter is a digital circuit that stores and counts pulses.
register: A register is a group of flip-flops used to store binary data.
power supply: A power supply provides the necessary electrical energy to operate electronic circuits.
transformer: A transformer is a device that changes voltage levels using electromagnetic induction.
eddy current: Eddy currents are loops of electric current induced within conductors by changing magnetic fields.
hysteresis: Hysteresis is the lag between applied magnetic field and magnetization of a material.
